Maybe the photographer knows or saw something.
Both the victim and the person charged were of "no fixed address", which just means homeless so one would assume it was a fight amongst those guys that hang out in that area.

Agreed the date is later. There's a Hewlett Packard DeskJet 500c printer in the background (on the left hand side). That wasn't built until 1991:
http://www.hpmuseum.net/display_item.php?hw=308
and not in wide circulation until 1992 or 1993.

Wouldn't it be interesting if Rachel and Ferdinand became the new Donnie and Alison? Living in the suburbs, participating in the community and church groups and so on. Alison and Donnie would be on the lam, running from the law and take up a new career as international drug couriers!
Yes, I think it's kind of like that long standing joke about "Lassie" where "Timmy fell down a well" if that makes any sense to everyone.

I don't think Sarah will die because this will leave Kira without a mother, which would just be repeat Sarah's childhood. They could bring back Cal but I think he'd want to take Kira away, which might not go over well with Siobhan who would no doubt be overwhelmed with grief after Sarah's death. Siobhan could go back to raising Kira but somehow this doesn't seem likely.

I think it's possible they may try to mess with Sarah and Felix's bond by doing something with Felix's half-sister, Adele. Perhaps Sarah will find out more about Adele's past, figure out she's shady or even lying then have to hurt or kill her.
This could create a nice character arc for both Sarah and Felix as they struggle to put their strained relationship back together. Let's face it - they're not as close as they were in season 1.
It's more than just what's conveyed in the photo. You needed to see their personalities and how they were on camera during interviews. Farrah just had that "it" factor.
Just wait until the soap gets added. Then everything goes to shit!

WRITING.TITLE: Death Pool for Season 5 - post your thoughts here!
WRITING.TEXT: Clone-wise I think Helena will die. Clone-adjacent: maybe Siobhan. I think Delphine is safe. Not Art or any of the other "civilian' bystanders.

I'm thinking more like, "these two characters need to break up because that's what we do on television shows and in films" then EB's not available so, "ok, good thing they're broken up as the actor has scheduling conflicts" situation.
Edit to add: I don't think they'll mention the breakup in the next season. The two characters may have some type of discussion about where they stand but depending on EB's availability and how this whole island thing unfolds I think it will likely just pick up where it was before.
OP has a cat. Or some other beast shedding all over their mouse pad.
I think any angst between those two was initially for dramatic effect and eventually because it suited Evelyne's schedule.

In the quote above Richard implies that the storyline was designed to save money as his character wouldn't have as much screen time. Not sure if this is true or just his interpretation. Or maybe his way of making light of it.
Kira. I think hers should have a removable head to signify her quick healing and also her psychic abilities.
Thanks! I always wondered about that poster.

Came here to discuss exactly that section of the article!
I guess it's pretty clear how he feels about what was done to his character. Rightfully so. I'm sure many actors get attached to their roles, invested in them and perhaps see them as an extension of themselves. Understandable especially if you've been playing it for years and components of it resonant with you personally.
Forgot to address your question about it with respect to OB. Whole different genre/style so I wouldn't think a comparison would be useful.

I've seen the first episode of "Thirteen". I plan on watching the remainder.
Thus far it reminds me of the American television show "The Family", which was on ABC with Joan Allen this past year. In that show their son returns home after having been abducted for many years. Unfortunately it was cancelled. There were a lot of plot holes but it was still enjoyable to watch IMHO.
It's also a bit like the film "Room" but both "Thirteen" and "The Family" take place when the child is older and has been freed.
Yes, thanks I know where you mean. I will check it out.
They're not screws on this one but rather a slot and tab system. Already broke one when I put the assembled hose/bracket/plastic piece in the window to test it out ;)

I think I will try some clamps on the chair. It just keeps jumping around and if I ruin it I'm basically screwed. It's really hard to get it started because of the lip at the edge of both sides. Another problem is that I'm used to having access to a good workshop (my father's but he passed away). Thanks for your help.

The plastic piece has a hole cut in it to accommodate the exhaust hose. There are proprietary plastic rings that connect the exhaust hose to the plastic frame I need to cut. Replacing this plastic piece with plywood is therefore not an option.

Yes, thanks. I know what tool to use. I don't really have a good way to brace it. The plastic piece is hard to cut and even harder to start a good groove that will hold the saw while cutting. I've already tried.
The plastic has a lip at the edge (see photo I posted) making it very hard to start the and keep the saw at the right spot. I've tried with the plastic piece on a chair using my knee to hold it in place and using a hack saw. It just jumps around all over the place and I can't get an even cut.

Yes, quite valid.
I'm starting to wonder about what the writers are thinking regarding Jude. First there was the hints he might be trans. I guess he doesn't wear nail polish anymore?? Then that he was gay, for a brief period he was interested in a girl or was that him trying to be straight? Wasn't there supposed to be a storyline about him becoming religious after that other foster kid was killed? It seems like some storylines have been dropped.
I also there was some type of drama behind the scenes either with these actors or maybe their mothers who are on set as per the rules for minors. Both knew their sons would be playing gay characters but that doesn't mean they liked where the storyline went or might have had some personal friction.
Edit to add: Agreed a relationship between two 14 year olds wouldn't have lasted. But they didn't have to write Connor off the show so abruptly, definitively and in a way that seemed a bit forced.
num ^ 6

The Hydro map has been updated. Looks substantial:
http://imgur.com/SbZiYhp
Hopefully they will update their map otherwise it's kinda useless.

Affecting 1 to 50 people according to Toronto Hydro Outage map:
http://www.torontohydro.com/sites/electricsystem/poweroutages/pages/outagemap.aspx

I've read different things online and I think there could be a few issues going on here.
One had to do with the mother of the actor (Gavin MacIntosh) who played Connor. I understand she didn't like what was going on at the set. Some of this may have had to do with the other actor (Jake T. Austin) that was playing Jesus. I'm not sure how much sense this makes as I don't think Connor and Jesus had many, if any scenes together. And Gavin MacIntosh left the show after Jake T. Austin so if he was an issue presumably it was resolved. Maybe it was/is just an overall difficult set.
If it is the actual storyline I don't think it's really all that unprecedented. Other shows like Degrassi had teenagers in same sex relationships years ago. As for more contemporary comparisons to shows like Pretty Little Liars one of its characters Emily (Shay Mitchell) become involved with another girl while in high school. I don't know what age the characters were supposed to be but the actors portraying them are in real life much older than those playing Jude and Conner.
So perhaps it's because the two young actors on The Fosters are much closer in age to the characters they portray and that's what really issue. It's freaking people out because they are actually that young. It's fine for Shay Mitchell whose portraying Emily on Pretty Little Liars to make out with another girl because she really wasn't 14 or 16 years old when that storyline was depicted.
Thank you! I recognized his voice but couldn't place him.

I thought the whole idea of having Donna stand up for herself, quit working for Josh, get hired by Will Bailey on Russell's campaign (presumably because he saw she had a skill set), basically excel (with a few missteps) in that role and end up working in the Santos campaign was to demonstrate there was more to her than maybe even the viewers were aware of. So I can see the writers trying to acknowledge her growth and provide her character with a career trajectory. As for Amy in that job when Abbey Bartlet was FLOTUS - I thought she was overqualified and not suited to the position at the time. So did the writers in the end ;)
I think there was some schmaltziness in the way they tried to wrap up the storylines. For example, Annabeth Schott as First Lady's Press Secretary. I'm assuming the character was qualified. I just feel like they were trying too hard to wrap everything up in a nice bow.
I don't think anyone was hired as Press Secretary. The last person in that position was Will and we know he left. Any suggestions for that job?
Here's a list of characters that includes reference to their status at the end of the show:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_The_West_Wing_characters

Yes, I though that too! It seems like a respectable position but I thought Donna deserved a job that had a more direct role in relation to governing, especially since it's not clear whether this First Lady (Helen Santos) would have her own policy agenda or take a more ceremonial role. It felt like to me that Donna was going to end up handling the FLOTUS' schedule and being wasted in that position.
I also didn't like what they did with Ronna Beckman by giving her Debbie Fiderer's job as Executive Secretary to the President. I thought she served as a strategist during the campaign and would work in the White House in a position that suited those skills.
Also what happened to Louise "Lou" Thornton? They managed to find a role for Amy Gardner in the Santos administration. I guess we are to assume Lou wasn't interested.
The last episode was very much a wrap up for all the characters, even the smaller roles. Some of it felt forced though.

Ok, I just re-watched that part of S7E1. It takes place 3 years later.
CJ and Danny are living in Santa Monica.
Bartlet to Toby, "How's Columbia"?, Toby states, "Not such a bad place to spend some time". I had assumed it was the university but I guess it could be the country due to the way it's worded. Makes less sense though.
There's no information provided about Charlie either way.
I was guessing that Kate and Will are not together because they're not standing beside each other (and nothing to indicate otherwise).
Some other things left open:
1. Do we know if Baker is ever confirmed as Vice President? 2. Can we assume Amy takes Santos offer to join the administration as we see her in episodes later on? 3. I guess due to timelines of the last season we never find out about Ellie and Vic's child.

Yes, that happened in the series finale. I'm referring to the flash forward episode (S7E1) that provides us with a glimpse of what happened a few years after the series finale (S7E22). I think I'll just re-watch it and see if I can pick up anything more.

WRITING.TITLE: Just watched the series finale and I have a few questions...
WRITING.TEXT:
...about what we're supposed to surmise based on the flash forward episode earlier that season (S7E1), which takes place at the opening of President Bartlet's library:
1. CJ and Danny: together and have a child. 2. Will Bailey and Kate Harper: Will has been elected to the Congress in Oregon, Kate just finished a book but no reference to them being together. I take it they are not. 3. Josh and Donna: Josh is at the library opening and still working for Santos. Presumably still with Donna. 4. Charlie and Zoey: Charlie has (or is about to, can't remember) graduated from law school, Zoey not mentioned. I think they might be together. 5. Toby is present but I can't recall what was said about him.
Did I miss anything?
Edit: changed reference to S7E1 to "flash forward" from "flashback" for clarity.

I've just watched "Election Day, Part 2" the episode where Leo dies. Bartlet reflects on their first meeting, how it was an argument about monetary role of the fed. He also states they almost lost him 15 years ago but doesn't go into details (must have been addiction issues). So for sure he knew him for at least15 years. I don't recall the dates for when Bartlet was in office.
Also when the announcement is made about his death on television the reporter states that Leo was a vice presidential candidate, White House counsellor, Chief of Staff, labor secretary, a captain of industry as well as a decorated Vietnam war veteran. It was also stated that Leo also played a major role in shaping every presidential election in the past quarter century. So if Bartlet was heavily involved in the Democratic Party back then he may have known Leo for at least 25 years.
Yup, that's an English Springer Spaniel. My family always has this type of dog. They're not as popular as they used to be though.
The person who took the picture is shown in the mirror on the wall above everyone.

Kind of interesting that this post was created by artificial intelligence (the bot) for an article about this particular show. However, the "mistake" about the ending, which I agree the article made was done by a human ( the author of the paper). So AI ended up,highlighting human error. Sort of meta.

WRITING.TITLE: [SPOILER] POI Amy Acker Dallas Fan Expo Panel, June 4th, 2016

WRITING.TEXT:
I acknowledge that the phrase, "rotation in pathology" is one you would most commonly associate with a medical residency program. However, it is possible for PhD students to take classes, do practicums and audit courses in closely related fields depending on their research focus. I know someone from grad school who spent one year in medical school as it pertained to his PhD research.
I have to admit I did start to wonder if they were retconning Delphine's education from a PhD to PhD/MD program. Some of the comments made (like above) and procedures she's performed could imply she might be a PhD/MD. I consider this logistically unlikely but if the writers want to make it so there's nothing stopping them.

I should have been more specific. It was the itemized list of 20+ "decorations" that were spotted in the fish bowl over the course of the show. I recall some of them but would not have known that there was that many nor would I have been able to name but a few.
Social justice.

Regarding the episode with Leo's death does anyone recall if there were any interviews with the cast about shooting it after it aired?
It would be interesting to hear how they dealt with their feelings.
I'm sure many actors are holding back tears when doing scenes acknowledging the loss of a character when an actor leaves a show. Sure they're sad because they won't be working with that person again. But at least they are still alive in real life.

During the First World War the Regiment raised three battalions for the Canadian Expeditionary Force, the 15th, the 92nd and the 134th. From its initial baptism of fire at the Second Battle of Ypres in April 1915 to the end of the war, the Regiment was awarded a total of 21 Battle Honours.
Source: http://www.army-armee.forces.gc.ca/en/48-highlanders/history.page
During the Great War, the 15th Battalion, CEF, was authorized on 1 September 1914 and embarked for Britain on 26 September 1914 and arrived in France on 15 February 1915. The Battalion fought as part of the 3rd Infantry Brigade, 1st Canadian Division in France and Flanders throughout the war. The 15th Battalion was disbanded on 30 August 1920. The 92nd Battalion (48th Highlanders), CEF was authorized on 30 July 1915 and embarked for Britain on 20 May 1916, where the battalion provided reinforcements to the Canadian Corps in the field until 24 January 1917, when its personnel were absorbed by the 5th Reserve Battalion, CEF before being disbanded on 1 September 1917. The 134th Battalion was authorized on 22 December 1915 and embarked for Britain on 8 August 1916, where it provided reinforcements to the Canadian Corps in the field until 7 March 1918, when its personnel were absorbed by the 12th Reserve Battalion, CEF. The battalion was then disbanded on 29 November 1918
Source: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/48th_Highlanders_of_Canada
As was that tiny tear that rolled down her cheek.

Lots of subs focusing on television shows are still running years after the show is gone (r/thewire, r/thewestwing, for example). Some organize re-watches. I think that would work well here. After an appropriate mourning period of course.

Yes, I've thought that as well. The pairing seemed odd. I like both characters on their own but together not so much. However, one of the scenes in which we are first introduced to their budding romance did introduce me to Dave Brubeck's "Take Five" for which I'm eternally grateful.
I'm sure Josh Malina will provide us with some insight into this in his podcast.
Re Cosima: what part of lesbian do you not understand?

Two things bug me the most: in real life the physicians are no where near that involved with the patients or their lives. At best they speak with them for a minute or so. The nurses have way more interaction with patients and their families.
The other thing is the number of scenes in which physicians are reading film. How many times are scenes set up where the main cast are getting consults while viewing film? It's the radiologist that reads film. None of the main characters are radiologists. Also they are always there when the patient is having a CT or MR. That's a technician's job. Also virtually no hospitals use view boxes anymore.
Helena is unintentionally funny. At times the audience is laughing at her and not with her.

I don't think the writers will use Kira as that type of plot device again. They've already had her hit by a car, in harms way and on the run.

Children of parents who speak English (for example) with accent who are raised in a country in which it's the primary language like most parts of Canada learn from their peers at school and not from their parents at home. That's why they speak it without an accent.
I'm Canadian. It's easy for me to understand Sandra's accent ;)

If you look (or listen) closely Sandra accidentally calls Jackson by his real name Jesse when they meet in the hallway of the hospital at one point during that episode. I'm surprised no one caught it in post.
Must be show and tell day at school.
